newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore sees healthcare output up 10 pct a year.
newsitem.headline: Singapore sees healthcare output up 10 pct a year.

text.p: Singapore expects output in the healthcare industry, which includes pharmaceuticals and biotechnology, to grow by 10 percent a year in the medium-term, the Economic Development Board (EDB) said on Monday.

"We see the sector growing at more than 10 percent a year over the medium-term," Tan Suan Swee, EDB director for the Chemicals & Biotechnology Industry Development Division, said at a briefing on the industry.
An EDB official later explained medium-term meant "over the next few years".

Tan said the healthcare industry manufactured goods worth Singapore $2.2 billion (US$1.56 billion) in 1996, up 10 percent over the previous year. Gross value added grew at a higher rate of 12 percent to S$1.7 billion, he said.
Singapore has about 80 companies, mainly multinationals, in the sector, including Glaxo Wellcome Plc, SmithKline Beecham and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer.
The EDB said the pharmaceuticals sector expanded by 11 percent in 1996.
To encourage more companies to set up a manufacturing base in Singapore, Tan said a 50-hectare (123-acre) site had been set aside in the western part of Singapore.
